messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 24, 2018 - October 30, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-31T20:59:05Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-10-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181031-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=2 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-10-27. Solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2018-10-28.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-11-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently no active regions present on the visible solar disk that have potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-11-04.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 10, 2018 - October 16, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-17T18:21:13Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-10-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181017-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.      
   
Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-10-10T18:00Z-21:00Z and 2018-10-13T15:00Z-18:00Z. The first slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2018-10-07. The solar wind speed reached values of 600 km/s on 2018-10-09. The second increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of another coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2018-10-13. The solar wind speed reached values of 550-600 km/s on 2018-10-14 and 2018-10-15.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2018-10-10 and continued to be elevated until 2018-10-13. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES-13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival on 2018-10-07 described above (see notifications 20181010-AL-001 and 20181012-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-10-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-10-20.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-12T20:16:03Z
## Message ID: 20181012-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20181008-AL-002 and 20181010-AL-001. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-10-08T18:35Z and remain above 10^5 pfu, currently around 186,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-10-07T06:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-10-08T18:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

The United States Government disclaims all warranties and liabilities regarding third party data and/or information, if present in the data and/or information generated and / or compiled by the NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, and distributes it "as is".

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 03, 2018 - October 09, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-10T19:18:08Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-10-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181010-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.      

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-10-07T15:00Z - 2018-10-08T00:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around mid-day on 2018-10-07. The solar wind speed reached values of 600 km/s on 2018-10-09.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-10-08T18:35Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES-13 were associated with the high speed stream arrival on 2018-10-07Z, described above (see notifications 20181008-AL-001 and 20181008-AL-002).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-10-16T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a high speed stream around 2018-10-13 with speeds up to 550-600km/s .


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-10T18:56:25Z
## Message ID: 20181010-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20181008-AL-001 and 20181008-AL-002. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-10-08T18:35Z and remains elevated, currently around 85,000 pfu, with the latest threshold crossing at 2018-10-10T17:10Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-10-07T06:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-10-08T18:35:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Auto-generated Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-08T18:47:37Z
## Message ID: 20181008-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-10-08T18:35Z. 


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 26, 2018 - October 02, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-10-03T18:57:06Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-09-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-10-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181003-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
  

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.      
  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-10-01T12:00Z-15:00Z and 2018-10-02T00:00Z-03:00Z. 


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-10-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-10-09T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are a few small or decayed active regions currently visible at the solar surface that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-10-04.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
